message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest muscular dystrophy, which is commonly caused by missense mutations. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are associated with certain types of genetic disorders, but not muscular dystrophy. Splice site mutations result in abnormal RNA splicing, which may lead to genetic disorders but is not a typical cause of muscular dystrophy. Frameshift mutations result from the insertion or deletion of nucleotides in the DNA sequence, which can cause genetic disorders, but again, are not a common cause of muscular dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a missense mutation in the DMD gene on the X chromosome. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are seen in certain other genetic disorders such as Huntington's disease and Fragile X syndrome, but not in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Splice site mutations and frameshift mutations can also cause genetic disorders, but they are not the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest muscular dystrophy, and among the options, only missense mutation is associated with muscular dystrophy. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are associated with Huntington’s disease and Fragile X syndrome, splice site mutations are associated with beta-thalassemia, and frameshift mutations are associated with cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Progressive difficulty climbing stairs, enlarged calf muscles, and waddling gait suggest muscular dystrophy, which is commonly caused by a missense mutation in the DMD gene. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are more commonly associated with neurodegenerative disorders such as Huntington's disease. Splice site mutation and frameshift mutation can both result in abnormal splicing or premature termination of protein synthesis, but they are not commonly associated with muscular dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of enlarged calf muscles and difficulty climbing stairs suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by missense mutations in the DMD gene. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are associated with other types of muscular dystrophy, while splice site and frameshift mutations can cause a variety of genetic diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical findings suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a missense mutation in the dystrophin gene. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are seen in conditions such as Huntington’s disease and spinal muscular atrophy, but not in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Splice site and frameshift mutations can also cause muscular dystrophy, but in this case, the patient’s condition is most likely due to a missense mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest a muscular dystrophy, and among the options, only missense mutation has been associated with muscular dystrophies such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Trinucleotide repeat expansions are associated with other conditions such as Huntington's disease and Fragile X syndrome. Splice site mutations and frameshift mutations can cause genetic diseases, but are not typically associated with muscular dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of progressive muscle weakness, which is commonly associated with missense mutations in the dystrophin gene that causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Trinucleotide repeat expansions are associated with other genetic disorders such as Fragile X syndrome and Spinocerebellar ataxia. Splice site and frameshift mutations can also cause genetic disorders but are less commonly associated with muscle weakness.

Trinucleotide repeat expansions are associated with other genetic disorders such as Huntington's disease. Splice site mutations and frameshift mutations are less commonly associated with muscular dystrophy.

Trinucleotide repeat expansions are seen in conditions such as Huntington's disease and Fragile X syndrome, but are not associated with muscular dystrophy. Splice site mutations and frameshift mutations may also cause muscular dystrophy, but are less common causes.
